rev.comment: This image use does not comply with [[WP:NFCC]] #10c and MUST be removed until it does. Thank you.
rev.diff:
Line 25: Line 25:
==History==
==History==
===Early years===
===Early years===
â
[[Image:Mosaic Netscape logo.png|thumb|100px|The logo of Mosaic Communications Corporation and its browser]]
 
Netscape was the second company to attempt to capitalize on the (then) nascent [[World Wide Web]]. It was originally founded under the name, '''Mosaic Communications Corporation''', on April 4, 1994, the brainchild of [[James H. Clark|Jim Clark]] who had recruited [[Marc Andreessen]] as co-founder and [[Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers]] as investors. Clark recruited other early Netscape team members from [[Silicon Graphics|SGI]] and [[NCSA Mosaic]], including [[Rosanne Siino]] who became Vice President of Communications. The company's first product was the web browser, called ''Mosaic Netscape 0.9,'' released on October 13, 1994. This browser was subsequently renamed [[Netscape Navigator]], and the company took the 'Netscape' name on November 14, 1994<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.holgermetzger.de/netscape/NetscapeCommunicationsNewsRelease.htm| title=Mosaic Communications changes name to "Netscape Communications Corporation"|accessdate=2006-09-14|publisher=Netscape Communications Corporation}}</ref> to avoid trademark ownership problems with [[National Center for Supercomputing Applications|NCSA]], where the initial Netscape employees had previously created the [[Mosaic (web browser)|NCSA Mosaic]] web browser. The Mosaic Netscape web browser used some NCSA Mosaic code with NCSA's permission, as noted in the application's "About" dialog box. Netscape made a very successful [[initial public offering|IPO]] on August 9, 1995. The stock was set to be offered at $14 per share. But, a last-minute decision doubled the initial offering to $28 per share. The stock's value soared to $75 on the first day of trading, nearly a record for first-day gain. The company's revenues doubled every quarter in 1995.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.wired.com/wired/archive/8.08/loudcloud.html?pg=4| title=Going Public as Netscape Did, before making a dime in profits | publisher=Lycos | work=Wired 8.08 | author=David Sheff | accessdate=2006-07-14}}</ref> Netscape's success landed Andreessen, barefoot, on the cover of [[Time Magazine]]<ref name="Time">{{cite web
Netscape was the second company to attempt to capitalize on the (then) nascent [[World Wide Web]]. It was originally founded under the name, '''Mosaic Communications Corporation''', on April 4, 1994, the brainchild of [[James H. Clark|Jim Clark]] who had recruited [[Marc Andreessen]] as co-founder and [[Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers]] as investors. Clark recruited other early Netscape team members from [[Silicon Graphics|SGI]] and [[NCSA Mosaic]], including [[Rosanne Siino]] who became Vice President of Communications. The company's first product was the web browser, called ''Mosaic Netscape 0.9,'' released on October 13, 1994. This browser was subsequently renamed [[Netscape Navigator]], and the company took the 'Netscape' name on November 14, 1994<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.holgermetzger.de/netscape/NetscapeCommunicationsNewsRelease.htm| title=Mosaic Communications changes name to "Netscape Communications Corporation"|accessdate=2006-09-14|publisher=Netscape Communications Corporation}}</ref> to avoid trademark ownership problems with [[National Center for Supercomputing Applications|NCSA]], where the initial Netscape employees had previously created the [[Mosaic (web browser)|NCSA Mosaic]] web browser. The Mosaic Netscape web browser used some NCSA Mosaic code with NCSA's permission, as noted in the application's "About" dialog box. Netscape made a very successful [[initial public offering|IPO]] on August 9, 1995. The stock was set to be offered at $14 per share. But, a last-minute decision doubled the initial offering to $28 per share. The stock's value soared to $75 on the first day of trading, nearly a record for first-day gain. The company's revenues doubled every quarter in 1995.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.wired.com/wired/archive/8.08/loudcloud.html?pg=4| title=Going Public as Netscape Did, before making a dime in profits | publisher=Lycos | work=Wired 8.08 | author=David Sheff | accessdate=2006-07-14}}</ref> Netscape's success landed Andreessen, barefoot, on the cover of [[Time Magazine]]<ref name="Time">{{cite web
| url=http://www.time.com/time/covers/0,16641,1101960219,00.html
| url=http://www.time.com/time/covers/0,16641,1101960219,00.html
Line 47: Line 46:
===Acquisition by America Online===
===Acquisition by America Online===
{{Citations missing|section|date=October 2008}}
{{Citations missing|section|date=October 2008}}
â
[[Image:Netscape throbber 2.gif|frame|Netscape logo as a [[throbber]]]]
 
[[America Online]] (AOL) on November 24, 1998 announced it would acquire Netscape Communications in a tax-free stock-swap valued at US$4.2 billion at the time of the announcement. This merger was ridiculed by many who believed that the two corporate cultures could not possibly mesh; one of its most prominent critics was longtime Netscape developer [[Jamie Zawinski]].[15][16] The acquisition was seen as a way for AOL to gain a bargaining chip against Microsoft, to let it become less dependent on the Internet Explorer web browser. Others believed that AOL was interested in Netcenter, or Netscape's web properties, which drew some of the highest traffic worldwide. Eventually, Netscape's server products and its Professional Services group became part of iPlanet, a joint marketing and development alliance between AOL and Sun Microsystems. On November 14, 2000, AOL released Netscape 6, based on the Mozilla 0.6 source code. (Version 5 was skipped.) Unfortunately, Mozilla 0.6 was far from being stable yet, and so the effect of Netscape 6 was to further drive people away from the Netscape brand. It was not until August 2001 that Netscape 6.1 appeared, based on Mozilla 0.9.2 which was significantly more robust. A year later came Netscape 7.0, based on the Mozilla 1.0 core.
[[America Online]] (AOL) on November 24, 1998 announced it would acquire Netscape Communications in a tax-free stock-swap valued at US$4.2 billion at the time of the announcement. This merger was ridiculed by many who believed that the two corporate cultures could not possibly mesh; one of its most prominent critics was longtime Netscape developer [[Jamie Zawinski]].[15][16] The acquisition was seen as a way for AOL to gain a bargaining chip against Microsoft, to let it become less dependent on the Internet Explorer web browser. Others believed that AOL was interested in Netcenter, or Netscape's web properties, which drew some of the highest traffic worldwide. Eventually, Netscape's server products and its Professional Services group became part of iPlanet, a joint marketing and development alliance between AOL and Sun Microsystems. On November 14, 2000, AOL released Netscape 6, based on the Mozilla 0.6 source code. (Version 5 was skipped.) Unfortunately, Mozilla 0.6 was far from being stable yet, and so the effect of Netscape 6 was to further drive people away from the Netscape brand. It was not until August 2001 that Netscape 6.1 appeared, based on Mozilla 0.9.2 which was significantly more robust. A year later came Netscape 7.0, based on the Mozilla 1.0 core.
===Disbanding ===
===Disbanding ===
â
[[Image:Netscape classic logo.png|thumb|left|128px|Netscape logo used from 1994 until 2002]]
 
After the Microsoft antitrust case found that Microsoft held and had abused monopoly power, AOL filed a suit against it for damages.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://news.com.com/2100-1001-820227.html| title=AOL's Netscape Sues Microsoft|accessdate=2006-07-14}}</ref> This suit was settled in May 2003 when Microsoft paid US $750 million to AOL and agreed to share some technologies, including granting AOL a license to use and distribute Internet Explorer royalty-free for seven years.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://news.com.com/2100-1032-1011296.html| title=Microsoft to pay AOL $750 Million|accessdate=2006-07-14}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://news.com.com/2100-1032_3-1011356.html| title=Is this the end of Netscape?|accessdate=2006-07-14}}</ref> This was considered to be the death knell for Netscape.
After the Microsoft antitrust case found that Microsoft held and had abused monopoly power, AOL filed a suit against it for damages.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://news.com.com/2100-1001-820227.html| title=AOL's Netscape Sues Microsoft|accessdate=2006-07-14}}</ref> This suit was settled in May 2003 when Microsoft paid US $750 million to AOL and agreed to share some technologies, including granting AOL a license to use and distribute Internet Explorer royalty-free for seven years.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://news.com.com/2100-1032-1011296.html| title=Microsoft to pay AOL $750 Million|accessdate=2006-07-14}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://news.com.com/2100-1032_3-1011356.html| title=Is this the end of Netscape?|accessdate=2006-07-14}}</ref> This was considered to be the death knell for Netscape.

Line 126: Line 119:
===Mozilla Thunderbird-based releases===
===Mozilla Thunderbird-based releases===
====Netscape Messenger 9====
====Netscape Messenger 9====
â
[[Image:NetscapeMessenger9.PNG|thumb|Netscape Messenger 9.0a1]]
 
{{Main|Netscape Messenger 9}}
{{Main|Netscape Messenger 9}}
On June 11, 2007, Netscape announced Netscape Mercury, a stand-alone Email / News Client that was to accompany Navigator 9. Mercury was based on [[Mozilla Thunderbird]].<ref>[http://community.netscape.com/n/pfx/forum.aspx?tsn=1&nav=messages&webtag=ws-nscpbrowser&tid=8688 Netscape Mercury in progress] Retrieved on [[11 June|06-011]]-2007</ref> The product was later renamed Netscape Messenger 9, and an alpha version was released. In December 2007, AOL announced it was canceling Netscape's development of Messenger 9 as well as Navigator 9.
On June 11, 2007, Netscape announced Netscape Mercury, a stand-alone Email / News Client that was to accompany Navigator 9. Mercury was based on [[Mozilla Thunderbird]].<ref>[http://community.netscape.com/n/pfx/forum.aspx?tsn=1&nav=messages&webtag=ws-nscpbrowser&tid=8688 Netscape Mercury in progress] Retrieved on [[11 June|06-011]]-2007</ref> The product was later renamed Netscape Messenger 9, and an alpha version was released. In December 2007, AOL announced it was canceling Netscape's development of Messenger 9 as well as Navigator 9.

Line 179: Line 170:
===Propeller===
===Propeller===
â
[[Image:NetscapePropeller.png|thumb|right|200px|Propeller logo]]
 
{{Main|Propeller.com}}
{{Main|Propeller.com}}
Netscape also operates the site [http://www.propeller.com Propeller], which is a [[social news]] aggregator, similar to [[Digg]], and formally known as Netscape.com between June 2006 and September 2007.
Netscape also operates the site [http://www.propeller.com Propeller], which is a [[social news]] aggregator, similar to [[Digg]], and formally known as Netscape.com between June 2006 and September 2007.
Line 196: Line 186:
===Netscape Internet Service===
===Netscape Internet Service===
â
[[Image:Netscape Internet Service logo.png|thumb|Netscape ISP Logo]]
  â  
Netscape ISP is a 56 kbit/s dial-up service offered at $9.95 per month<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.getnetscape.com/index.adp | title=GetNetscape Home Page | accessdate=2008-03-20}}</ref> ($6.95 with 12-month commitment). The company serves webpages in a compressed format to increase effective speeds up to 1300 kbit/s (average 500 kbit/s). The [[Internet service provider]] is run by [[AOL]] under the Netscape brand. The low-cost ISP was officially launched on January 8, 2004.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.timewarner.com/corp/newsroom/pr/0,20812,670188,00.html | title=Netscape Launches Low-Cost Internet Access Service}}</ref> Its main competitor is [[NetZero]]. Netscape ISP's advertising is generally aimed at a younger demographic, e.g., [[college]] students, and people just out of school, as an affordable way to gain access to the Internet.
Netscape ISP is a 56 kbit/s dial-up service offered at $9.95 per month<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.getnetscape.com/index.adp | title=GetNetscape Home Page | accessdate=2008-03-20}}</ref> ($6.95 with 12-month commitment). The company serves webpages in a compressed format to increase effective speeds up to 1300 kbit/s (average 500 kbit/s). The [[Internet service provider]] is run by [[AOL]] under the Netscape brand. The low-cost ISP was officially launched on January 8, 2004.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.timewarner.com/corp/newsroom/pr/0,20812,670188,00.html | title=Netscape Launches Low-Cost Internet Access Service}}</ref> Its main competitor is [[NetZero]]. Netscape ISP's advertising is generally aimed at a younger demographic, e.g., [[college]] students, and people just out of school, as an affordable way to gain access to the Internet.
